properties.media:imagetext:
WATER LANDINGS
A water landing in a land aircraft is a highly unlikely event; however if this
remote possibility should occur, it is imperative that you be familiar with the
equipment on board and procedures for a safe and orderly exit into the life
rafts.
LIFE VESTS. Life vests, packed in a plastic pouch, are located underneath
your seats. The cabin attendants will instruct you as to their location, and
demonstrate the use of your life vest. (Life rafts and vests not on all
aircraft.)
CREW ASSIGNMENTS. Members of the crew will be assigned to the
passenger compartment. It may be necessary to ask you to move to a dif-
ferent location in the plane to facilitate evacuation of the aircraft. If so, your
prompt cooperation will be appreciated. Await instructions from the crew,
but be prepared to follow them explicitly.
DITCHING PROCEDURE. In the event it is necessary to land on water,
appropriate announcements will be made on the aircraft's public address
system, and the cabin attendant will instruct you as to the action to be
taken. Immediately after this warning proceed as follows:
1. Cease smoking or using cigarette lighters or matches, and don coat if
conveniently available.
2. Remove glasses, high-heeled shoes and sharp pocket objects, and
loosen collar and tie.
3. Put on vest as demonstrated, adjust straps so that vest fits snug. DO
NOT INFLATE AT THIS TIME.
4. Place seat in full upright position unless otherwise instructed by cabin
attendant.
5. Fasten seat belt tightly ... uncomfortably so. Assume the brace
position as instructed.
6. At P.A. announcement "Brace for impact," and six rapid call bells,
brace yourself for a minimum of two impacts. This will occur within a
few seconds. (Generally two shocks will be felt, the second slightly
more severe than the first.)
7. Do not move until the aircraft has come to a complete stop on the
water. Unfasten seat belts only when aircraft has reached a complete
stop. Remain in seat until instructed to board life raft by crew
members. Do not inflate life vest until after leaving aircraft.
LIFE RAFT PROCEDURE. After the water landing has been completed,
crew members will issue directions to your proper life raft station and will
tell you how and in what order to board the life raft. Normally one crew
member will be in each life raft and will be in charge. Sufficient life rafts for
all passengers and crew members are carried aboard all Ozark Air Lines ex-
tended over-water aircraft. Each raft is equipped for maximum safety and
for the most comfort possible.
AIR SEARCH AND RESCUE. The aircraft is in constant radio contact
with international air search and rescue bases. In the event of a water lan-
ding, this highly efficient organization goes into action. Radio-equipped
planes are instantly dispatched carrying droppable lifeboats and other
emergency equipment. All ships at sea are informed of the exact position of
the airplane in distress.
It is possible for these operations to be initiated hours before the water lan-
ding is actually performed and rescue procedures can be completed in a
matter of a few hours. A maximum of safety can be assured by following
precisely the instructions of crew members.
properties.wof:name: safety information card: Ozark Air Lines, Douglas DC-9 and McDonnell Douglas MD-82
